title: Fixes the NPE in CustomGrouping
body:
Current heron replaces the an existing PhysicalPlanHelper with a new old during update(), which is triggered by an incoming new PhysicalPlan.
However, it creates a new instance of CustomGrouping without initializing it, i.e. without invoking CustomStreamGrouping.prepare(..)

So it is very possible that during chooseTasks(..), topology developers uses a object, which is expected to be initialized in prepare(..) but turns out not initialized.

This pull request fixes this bug.
Tested and Verified in LocalScheduler.

title: Fixes the SIGSEGV during UpdateQueueMetrics from a restarted instance
body:
This pull request fixes the SIGSEGV during UpdateQueueMetrics from a restarted instance

Current stmgr will clean only connection_buffer_metric_map_ during HandleConnectionClose.
However, during HandleRegisterInstanceRequest(), before adding necessary meta-info, stmgr will check the existence of instance basing on instance_info_, which is not cleaned. So connection_buffer_metric_map_ will no longer contain the entry of instance once it is restarted, since it will not be added. And accessing to that entry returns SIGSEGV.

Besides that, this pull request also fixes potential memory leaks.

Tested and verified on LocalScheduler.

title: [Do not merge] change log FATAL to ERROR to avoid crashing stmgr
body:
There were corrupt events in EventBus which were crashing stream manager. With errors such as this:
last message is : F0120 09:03:24.136044 55260 client.cpp:226] UnPackString failed from connection 0x28da580 from hostport 10.44.144.115:31661

Heron should be resilient to such issues. Corrupt packets should be dropped and not crash the Stream Manager.

title: Add API support for backpressure metric (instance level) & display backpressure (instance level) in Heron UI
body:
a. heron_api.py:
 1. Added API support (`/topologies/metrics/timeline?metric=bp`) for new metric `back-pressure`. Created a new function `fetch_bp` since querying back-pressure data from tracker API is quite different from other metrics. Other metrics (gc, capacity, etc.) pass their component name and `*` as their instance name to query respective metric from Tracker API. On the other hand, bp metric is a part of `__stmgr__` component, which contains multiple instances (`__stmgr__1`, `__stmgr__2`, etc.).

Therefore, it is not possible to directly query back pressure data for each component present in the DAG. Instead, we need to query **each component's instance individually** for back pressure data `(DEFAULT(0, TS(__stmgr__,*,__time_spent_back_pressure_by_compid/{instance})))`.

2. Also added `get_instances` function to retrieve all instances from topology's physical plan. These instances names are used while querying back pressure data from Tracker API.
3. Added `compute_max` & `get_metric_response` functions which extract common LOC from `fetch` & `fetch_max` methods and are re-used by the `fetch_bp` method.
4. `fetch_max` method had a minor bug, where each component response was re-computed multiple times, since the logic for computing maximum value was included inside the for-loop block. This issue is also fixed in this commit.

b. plan-stats.js
1. Included back-pressure metric in the front-end. 
2. Currently, the following values have been configured for low, medium & high ranges: 3000, 12000, 30000. This means that if any instance of the topology is under back pressure for 0 - 3 seconds, then the health of that instance is marked as good. Similarly, if it is under back pressure for 3 - 12 seconds, then the health of that instance is marked as medium, and if it is between 12 - 30 seconds, then it is marked as bad.

title: [DO NOT MERGE] Initial Dhalion API for auto-scaling and tuning
body:
This is initial review request for Dhalion. The aim of this PR is to review Dhalion API and the general direction. This is work in progress.

Dhalion is a toolkit for auto-scaling and auto-tuning a topology dynamically. Highlights:
1.  Dhalion will provide a set of algorithms to monitor a topology (`ISymptomDetector.java`), correlate the observations to identify the problem (`IDiagnoser.java`) and potentially resolve the issue (`IResolver.java`).
1. The algorithms above will become the building blocks for a policy, `IHealthPolicy.java`. An admin would compose a health policy using one or more algorithm implementations and provide configuration to customize the behavior of the policy. 
1. A `HealthManager` will periodically execute the health policies to keep a running topology healthy. The `HealthManager` process could manage the topology using one or more policies. 
1. Dhalion depends on metrics provided by `heron-tracker` or `metrics-cache` and employs `heron update` feature to manage the topology configuration.
1. Some of the algorithms are generic and could be integrated with other streaming systems, for e.g. Storm. With this goal, we plan to keep the code in a separate package and minimize dependency on Heron.

Code structure
1. The core api's are part of `org/apache/dhalion/api/` package.
1. Implementation of the core api specific to Heron are in `org/apache/dhalion/heron` package.

title: [do not merge] Auto restart the container that has back pressure
body:
1. Motivation:
One of the most common alerts we get is back pressure, and one of the most typical resolutions is to restart the containers that have trouble and wait for the topology to come back.
This feature will automate the above 'detecting back pressure and restarting container' procedures.

2. Life cycle:
This feature is a temporary solution before the comprehensive SLA/HealthMgr is available. This feature heavily depend on TMetricsCollector and should retire along with TMetricsCollector.

3. User interface:
The 'heron.config.auto_heal_window' and 'heron.config.auto_heal_interval' config-propertys are required for 'submit' command:
```
heron submit ... [--config-property heron.config.auto_heal_window=<back pressure time window, integer, in minutes>] [--config-property heron.config.auto_heal_interval=<min restart interval, integer, in minutes>] ...
```
For example:
```
~/bin/heron submit --config-property heron.config.auto_heal_window=10 --config-property heron.config.auto_heal_interval=20 local ~/.heron/examples/heron-examples.jar com.twitter.heron.examples.ExclamationTopology ExclamationTopology --verbose
```
**heron.config.auto_heal_window**
- The feature is disabled, when:
a. the 'heron.config.auto_heal_window' config is missing, or
b. the `<back pressure time window>` is less than or equals to zero.
- if the `<back pressure time window>` is greater than zero, the back pressure metrics are monitored. If any container has been with back pressure for more than `<back pressure time window>` period, the container will be restarted.

**heron.config.auto_heal_interval**
- 'heron.config.auto_heal_interval' is to address the uncontrolled data loss, so that it is valid only if 'heron.config.auto_heal_window' is enabled.
- 'heron.config.auto_heal_interval' is 20 minutes by default, if it is missing.
- The elapsed time between any container restarting is at least `<min restart interval>`.

4. Solution description:
a. TMaster monitors the back pressure metrics.
b. If there has been the back pressure in the container X for more than `<back pressure time window>` minutes, TMaster sends a command to the heron-shell in the container X.
c. The heron-shell kills the heron-executor and the Aurora will re-schedule the container X.

title: Modifying configs at submit if numContainers is off
body:
Fixes #1742 by updating configs and the topology to match the number of containers specified by the packing plan. The key parts to look at is the `SubmitterMain.updateNumContainersIfNeeded` method.

Also moves this validation into `SubmitterMain` so it can happen before uploading the package. @ashvina I know we refactored to not build the packing plan in both `SubmitterMain` and `LaunchRunner`, but I think it makes sense to do this logic as early as possible, since we're mutating the user-provided topology and configs.

repo.description: Apache Heron (Incubating) is a realtime, distributed, fault-tolerant stream processing engine from Twitter

title: MetricsCacheMgr prototype
body:
This PR was https://github.com/huijunw/heron/pull/1.

The MetricsCacheMgr is a standalone process in container 0. It is responsible for collecting metrics from MetricsCacheSink and replying queries from both inside and outside process. It will eventually substitute the tmetrics-collector in the Tmaster. It currently may serve as the base process for SLA to be developed on.

The MetricsCacheMgr process sets its location in the StateMgr, which is monitored by StMgr and sent to MetricsMgr. MetricsCacheMgr provides three interfaces for metric publishing and querying:
1)publish metrics: MetricsCacheSink sends the metrics to the MetricsCacheMgr process. 
2)query from outside process: The protobuf message definition of Tmaster is re-used for future easy migration.
3)query from inside process: GetMetrics(MetricCacheRequest request)

To try it out on local Mac laptop, see below step A and step B.

#### [A] to run it locally on Mac laptop (same as normal procedures):
```Bash
git clone https://github.com/huijunw/heron.git
git checkout SLAMetricCache
cd [source root directory]

bazel build --config=darwin heron/...
bazel build --config=darwin scripts/packages:binpkgs
bazel build --config=darwin scripts/packages:tarpkgs

bazel-bin/scripts/packages/heron-api-install.sh --user 
bazel-bin/scripts/packages/heron-client-install.sh --user
bazel-bin/scripts/packages/heron-tools-install.sh --user

~/bin/heron submit local ~/.heron/examples/heron-examples.jar com.twitter.heron.examples.ExclamationTopology ExclamationTopology --deploy-deactivated --verbose
```

#### [B] to query:
in the [source root directory], do

```Bash
bazel run heron/metricscachemgr/src/java:metricscache-queryclient-unshaded -- ExclamationTopology exclaim1 __emit-count __execute-count __fail-count __ack-count __complete-latency __execute-latency __process-latency __jvm-uptime-secs __jvm-process-cpu-load __jvm-memory-used-mb __jvm-memory-mb-total __jvm-gc-collection-time-ms __server/__time_spent_back_pressure_initiated __time_spent_back_pressure_by_compid
```

title: use raw Map in storm api
body:
As part of coding style improvement, we previously changed the config type from raw Map to Map<String, Object> in storm directory. 

This causes incompatibility with the existing storm api and caused compilation failures in certain cases (e.g. topology written in scala).

In this PR, the raw Map is used again and all the warnings for it is suppressed. This change only happens in heron/storm directory.

title: Fixing bug in WebSink metrics collector
body:
I found a bug in the WebSink metrics collector, that I contributed a couple month ago.

If the metrics are getting exported in the hierarchical format, a new `MetricsRecord` would override and old `MetricsRecord` and the `MetricsInfo`s associated to it. Now a new `MetricsRecord` will merge the `MetricsInfo`s of an old `MetricsRecord`. A cache with expiration is used.

title: Removing sandbox enums that have duplicate concepts
body:
First pass of sandbox cleanup. Removed a ton of repetitive code and sandbox enums that had duplicate non-sandbox concepts. See the `Key` file for the main changes, as well as `ClusterConfig`, `Misc` simplification and new tests in `ClusterConfigTests`.

More work to be done in follow-up PRs:
- Refactor our `HERON_SANDBOX_JAVA_HOME` and possibly `HERON_SANDBOX_CONF` and `HERON_SANDBOX_HOME` from Key.
- Update `AuroraField` enum values and aurora configs to not use SANDBOX_FOO fields.
- Possibly remove `Context` since it's an unnecessary place for new configs to also be added?
- Rename `Misc` class.

title: Remove defaults.yaml in favor of enum Key approach
body:
Moving `defaults.yaml` functionality into `Key` enum and removing about 1k lines of code. This provides better typing, compile-time checks, elimination of resources, fewer config-related classes and fewer places to touch to add a config.

- The Defaults class is gone. That functionality is now handled by `ClusterConfig.loadConfig(String heronHome, String configPath, String releaseFile, String overrideConfigFile)` (used by production classes) and `Config.newBuilder(true)` (typically for unit tests).
- I still don't love the `ClusterConfig` class. I might refactor that in a follow-up PR if I can think of a cleaner way. 
- Now that a ton of cruft is gone, it would be good to refactor how we deal with sandbox configs to not be so clunky and repetitive.

title: Support connection buffer metrics between stmgr and instances
body:
The patch supports connection buffer metrics between stmgr and instances.
It exports the connection buffer metrics in both # of packets and # of bytes.
It will sample the metrics at an interval and then export the average value during every metrics-collection-interval.

Metric name format:
1. packets count
``__connection_buffer_by_intanceid/{instance-id}/packets``
2. bytes
``__connection_buffer_by_intanceid/{instance-id}/bytes``

Examples:
``__connection_buffer_by_intanceid/container_2_word_6/bytes``
``__connection_buffer_by_intanceid/container_2_word_6/packets``

This bases on @congwang : #1686

title: Replaces keys.yaml and Keys with Key enum
body:
(Replaces prototype PR at billonahill#5 with the full refactor)

Refactoring to no longer read keys from `keys.yaml`. All key usage is via `Key` enum and removing `keys.yaml` and `Keys`.  Core classes in this review are `Key` and `Config`. All others are refactors to use changes to those two classes.

Benefits:
- compile time checks of invalid keys
- easier refactoring
- remove complexity of bundling and reading `keys.yaml`
- more concise usage
- extensibility of `Key` metadata (e.g., type, default, required, etc)

After this I'd like to also remove `defaults.yaml` in favor of the enum approach.

title: Clean up config visiblity and dead code
body:
First commit of hopefully many to simplify config code.

- Removing dead config code
- Reducing scope of config methods to be as limited as it can be
- Simplifying config loading so `RuntimeManagerMain` and `SubmitterMain` don't need to load defaults and then load configs like this:

```
Config.Builder defaultsConfig = Config.newBuilder()
       .putAll(ClusterDefaults.getDefaults())
       .putAll(ClusterConfig.loadConfig(heronHome, configPath, releaseFile));
```

Instead, abstracting that in the API by having `loadConfig` properly initialize with defaults first.

title: Standardize Java formatter string.
body:
#### Problem
The current argument index is invalid, which will be rejected by some Java compiler (`jdk1.8.0_77` in internal OS X CI environment). See: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/Formatter.html#syntax. Even though some compilers do not reject this syntax, it is not valid according to language spec anyway.

#### Solution
Switch to ``%s``.

title: [dry-run] print with UTF-8 encoding and consume stream with UTF-8 decoding
body:
Since we are using UTF-8 character when rendering dry-run response, we need to take care of some UTF-8 locale issue. For example, in CI Ubuntu environment, the Java program does not print with UTF-8 encoding or consume input stream with UTF-8 decoding, which could cause at least two problems:
1. CLI outputs question marks instead of proper UTF-8 character
2. Unit test fails because input stream of sample output file is not decoded with UTF-8

Test has also been done in internal Linux environment.

title: Change AuroraController to an interface
body:
The current implementation of `AuroraController` shells out to the aurora cli and is intended to be run locally by a developer. Other implementations might call the aurora scheduler service directly. Changing `AuroraController` to be an interface allows other implementations to be used by `AuroraScheduler`.

The diff makes things appear messier than they are but basically `AuroraController` was renamed to `AuroraCLIController` and a new `AuroraController` interface was added.

title: Avoid notifying when no one is waiting on proceedLock
body: In one of our Heron jobs we found that the spout is spending 20-30% time in just calling notify in SlaveLooper. Notify happens to be an expensive call and in this case it seems that the invocation of notify is almost always redundant since SpoutInstance calls SlaveLooper from a single thread. Optimizing that here. The cost of optimization is two extra volatile writes while waiting and one extra volatile read in wakeUp. volatile reads are pretty fast so wouldn't add much overhead to wakeUp. volatile writes are slower but waits are less common and cost of volatile writes is much lower compared to wait.

title: DC/OS Support + Docker-based executors via Marathon
body:
- Main premise here is getting Heron to work on top of DCOS
- In order to do independent deployments on top of Mesos and not worry about what platform the underlying machines are running, I found it easier to just create a Docker image to run the executor on top of
- In order to get the executor to work nicely with Docker, I had to make a few modifications to the TMaster and STMgr files. The main reason behind this was that when you go out and get the hostname within a docker container, it'll give you the container id. So, as a result, the executors couldn't talk to the TM because the hostname was wrong. To fix this, I pushed the job of getting the hostname back to the python executor, where it looks at the environment for 'HOST' and if that's not present, then it grabs the hostname. 
- ~~Found a small bug in the process of trying to get the S3 Uploader to work~~ (someone else fixed it when merged with master

NOTE: I probably should do a bit more testing against my test cluster but I wanted to put this out there for comments before I go too deep
